sub_topic: Determining the degree sequence of a graph.
message_1: Consider a graph with 8 vertices and degree sequence {3, 3, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1}. Can you draw this graph? If no, explain why. If yes, draw the graph unique up to isomorphism.
message_2:
Yes, it is possible to draw a graph with 8 vertices and the given degree sequence {3, 3, 3, 2, 2, 1, 1, 1}. Here is a description of the graph unique up to isomorphism:

1. Label the vertices as A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H.
2. Assign the degrees as follows: deg(A) = 3, deg(B) = 3, deg(C) = 3, deg(D) = 2, deg(E) = 2, deg(F) = 1, deg(G) = 1, and deg(H) = 1.
3. Connect the vertices with the following edges: AB, AC, AD, BC, BE, CD, CF, and GH.

The resulting graph has the desired degree sequence and can be drawn as follows:

```
  A---B
 / \ / \
C---D---E
 \ / \ /
  F   G-H
```

This graph is unique up to isomorphism, meaning that any other graph with the same degree sequence can be transformed into this graph by relabeling the vertices.
